prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA – for wanting to use ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ to a mixed group
  

I play an online team game which is 99% male players. Recently we asked a girl to join our team, lets call her Jane. After match we often say stuff like ‘well done boiz’ and she told us that makes her feel like not part of the team and suggested we say something like ‘well done team’ instead. We all agreed to try, she is part of the team and as good as any of us guys. Jane has said it is difficult for a girl to play in an all male group but I don’t see why as we treat her well.

Yesterday one guy posted in group chat that he could not attend a practice and said ‘Have fun lads and Jane’. Jane responded by telling him that was worse than just saying ‘lads’ and made her feel ‘othered’.

The group had a bit of a chat about it and I said I was gonna keep using ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ because I mean the whole team when I say that and I am not giving in to radical feminism. 

The guy who started this though, said he was sorry for what he wrote and he was trying to include her and he would try to refer to team or people in future.

I ought to be able to use normal words without overly sensitive people feeling hurt by it. I am surprised that some of the other guys are taking her side though.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for using terms like "lads" and "guys" in a mixed group where a female teammate, Jane, feels excluded. 

First, the context is important. The team is almost entirely male, and Jane is the only girl. She's already pointed out that terms like "boiz" make her feel left out, so they agreed to use "team" instead. Then another guy slips up by saying "lads and Jane," which Jane finds even worse. The author defends using "lads" and "guys," saying they mean the whole team and not giving in to "radical feminism." 

Now, considering Jane's feelings, she's in a minority as a woman in a male-dominated group. The terms "lads" and "guys" are traditionally male, so even if the intention is to include everyone, the effect might still be exclusionary. The author's stance of not changing their language despite Jane's discomfort could be seen as dismissive. 

Also, the fact that other guys are taking Jane's side suggests that maybe the author is not the only one who's wrong, but the question is about the author specifically. The author's comment about not giving in to "radical feminism" might come off as disrespectful to Jane's valid feelings. 

So, even if the intention is inclusion, the impact matters. The author is choosing to stick with terms that Jane finds hurtful. That's probably where the wrong lies—not in the words themselves, but in ignoring the teammate's feelings. The right approach would be to use more inclusive language as Jane suggested. Therefore, the answer is likely A.
